---
title: "6.2 - Using the Normal Distribution"
---

{{< include preamble.qmd >}}

The shaded area in the following graph indicates the area to the left of $x$. This area is represented by the probability of $P(X < x)$. Normal tables, computers, and calculators are used to provide or calculate the probability $P(X < x)$. 

```{r}
#| label: fig-plot1
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| fig-height: 3
#| fig-width: 4
library(ggplot2)

ggplot() + 
    theme_minimal(base_size = 14) + 
    theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),axis.line = element_line(colour = "black")) + 
    #stat_function(fun = dnorm, geom = "function", linewidth = 1, xlim = c(-3,1)) + 
    #stat_function(fun = dnorm, geom = "area", alpha = 0.5, fill = "lightblue", xlim = c(-1,1)) + 
    geom_area(aes(c(-3,3)), stat = "function", fun = dnorm, fill = "#00674E", xlim = c(-3,1)) +
    geom_area(aes(c(-3,3)), stat = "function", fun = dnorm, fill = "lightgrey", xlim = c(1,3)) + 
    stat_function(fun = dnorm, geom = "function") + 
    scale_x_continuous(labels = expression(x), breaks = c(1), limits = c(-3,3)) + 
    scale_y_continuous(labels = NULL) + 
    labs(y = "", x = "x") + 
    annotate(geom = 'text', x = 2, y = .3, 
        label = "Shaded area\nrepresents probability\nP(X<x)", size = 3)
```
